paragraphs.text: There have been many World War II stories told in film depicting triumphs of personal courage and survival

paragraphs.text: The story of Louis Zamperini is one such story, but with an added dimension

paragraphs.text: Zamperini, who died earlier this year at age 97, came home an angry man
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He became addicted to alcohol and cigarettes and verbally abused his young wife as he wrestled with his inner demons
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The skeleton of his story is in the film -- the plane crash at sea while on a rescue mission; the 47 days floating on a raft before being picked up by a Japanese ship and thrown into a prison camp; the relentless torture and eventual liberation at the end of the war
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: After returning to Los Angeles we see Zamperini hugging his brother and parents

paragraphs.text: Director Angelina Jolie attempts to put some flesh on the bones at the end of the film with some still shots and words that tell us that Zamperini's faith led him to return to Japan on a personal mission of reconciliation
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In media appearances, Jolie has refused to discuss why the most remarkable part of Zamperini's story was excluded from the film

paragraphs.text: That would be the night he was converted at the 1949 Billy Graham crusade in Los Angeles

paragraphs.text: As Hillenbrand tells it in her book, Louis came home, poured his alcohol down the drain, threw out his cigarettes, was reconciled to his wife and became a new man because, he said, he had asked Jesus Christ to be his savior
